text: I went up for to B the first time for a
meeting in 2003 so it's quite a while
ago now and I was there representing
this group called BCS women the British
computer Society women's group um so I
was going up there representing them and
I didn't really know much about
Bletchley Park on the way there in my
head I kind of thought maybe it was like
50 old bles kind of wearing Tweed
jackets smoking pipes and doing the
Times crossword on the side and maybe a
bit of code breaking so that was kind of
my idea and I think in those days
everyone kind of thought that's that's
what went on there
I found out on the first trip that um
more than 10,000 people worked there
which was a shock and that more than
half of them were women and being a
woman in Computing I was really
interested in that so uh ran um an oral
history project after that to um capture
the memories of the women that work
there HMS penbroke 5 was just an
umbrella word uh to cover the activities
that took place at Bletchley Park and so
at the launch of that I actually found
out that ble part were having financial
difficulties um so that's the first time
that I'd been aware of that and then I
was uh up at a reception just after that
at Bley Park and that's actually the
first time I did a proper tour of the
whole site that's when I saw that you
know the hearts that that looked like
they were falling down you know it's
like Heart Six with a blue tarping over
it um and had a proper tour with someone
who' who'd worked there during the
second world war and you know he was
telling us about all the major
codebreaking achievements in each of the
huts and um and I just thought well and
this place my close you know it was said
that the work that was done there
shortened the war by approximately 2
years 11 million people a year were
dying and I just thought it's ridiculous
you know we've got to do something about
it you're a computer Scientist by trade
aren't you what did it matter to you
about some code Breakers and people
solving
puzzles well I suppose it's all kind of
geeky and techy I I definitely am a geek
uh and you know I've got a degree in
Computing and a PhD in software
engineering so I guess I really am a
geek right and uh so there's a very
strong ction with the kind of all the
the math to start with um you know
there's loads of math in Computing and
the math in um sort of uh cryptography
and stuff um so you know I loved it from
from the geeky aspect but also you know
the human point of view and the fact
that all these people work there so kind
of had both for me really and and of
course the fact that there was about
8,000 women and and young women as well
so I didn't find that out till later but
they were mainly like between 18 and 23
the women so you know thousands of young
women you know and some young men a few
old men all together you know doing this
code breaking you know and kind of
trying to to save millions of lives it's
just an incredible Story by the time it
got to 2008 which is when I started the
campaign I uh was head of department at
University of Westminster so I was head
of a computer science department and you
know i' found out that Bley Park might
have to close because they didn't have
enough money and I just thought I've got
to do something about this so I emailed
all the other heads and professors of
computing in the country and asked them
to sign a petition which was on the
government website at the time and uh
and in those days you could look at the
names of the people that were signing so
you know I sent this email out and then
a few hours later I thought I'll see if
anyone signed it and I looked at the
petition there's all these famous
professors of computing from the UK and
I was like oh my goodness all these
professors you know think the same as me
we've got to do something about it so
that really gave me confidence to to
then take it further um so what we did
was we wrote a letter to the time so
that was signed by 97 heads and
professors um and also I contacted all
the journalists that I knew which in
those days was only about four but
luckily one of them was Rory kein Jones
from the BBC he got back in touch with
me and then got me on BBC News the next
week and so July 2008 I was on BBC News
saying I'm ashamed to be British we've
got to save Bletchley Park and that went
across the world which was amazing but
then I noticed that you know a few weeks
later I just thought well what can I do
now because I've made a big splash but
like nothing much is happening so it
wasn't until a few months after that
that I started using Twitter and social
media and then realized quite quickly
the potential of using particularly
Twitter for kind of finding people that
are interested in the same subject and
creating a social media campaign Blacky
Park is now quite quite a visitors
attraction isn't it I mean how's it feel
have you been back since much and tell
me about that I've probably been there
I've probably been to Bley Park I don't
know 50 100 times now um but I have to
say every time I go I I see something
different and find out something new so
um it's a very exciting place to visit
for me you know even now and uh you know
so there's Bletchley Park on one side
which is all the history and the
cryptography stuff then there's of
course the national museum of computing
which is on site there too uh both
equally um amazing attractions and um
yeah there's just so much there to see
I've you know I've probably been back
like I said about 50 times and um you
know there's all the codebreaking Huts
there there's stuff about the women that
work there there's uh the rebuild of
turing's bomb machine which is
incredible if you get a chance to see
that working at the Museum of computing
they've got Colossus working um you know
just these amazing machines uh which had
to be rebuilt because of course they
were all destroyed at the end of World
War II so there's some incredible
attractions there and I think the site
is about 26 Acres so you know it's a
really large site with something for
everyone so the campaign took about 3
years so we started with traditional
media then social media about 6 months
in and it took about another 2 and a
half years after that for the director
of Bletchley Park to actually say that
Bletchley Park wasn't you know it wasn't
ever going to close and that that it was
safe um because they got 4.1 million
Heritage Lottery funding which of course
you know substantially helped with uh uh
the renovation so so the book is the
story I've written the story of the
campaign what we did using social media
so it's kind of a primer in in how to
use social media in a campaign too um
but then that's also intercut with the
story of the women that work there of
enigma and uh touring and you know all
the things that you've probably heard
about would like to know more about that
that story is in there too so what's
next then have you got any more plans to
uh get bring back any more British
institutions of computing well I mean
actually my focus now is Tech moms so um

staying safe online and a bit of coding

Programming too um and uh the program is

too here we are at Bletchley Park but in
